rangees.data: External shoulder rotation, glenohumeral joint coaptation
Average of 4 points of muscle belly
Average of 2 points of muscle belly

subSection.title: Choice of Evaluation Position
text: Variant 1, below, is commonly used and allows good exposure of the posterolateral structures of the shoulder, particularly the infraspinatus and teres minor
Some authors [1] recommend variant 2 more. In some cases, variant 1 can cause excessive anteriorization of the teres minor tendon, making it difficult to distinguish from the infraspinatus.

subSection.title: Variant 1: Hand on Contralateral Shoulder
text: Seated with shoulder exposed
Shoulder:
Complete adduction
Internal rotation
Neutral flexion - extension
Elbow:
Flexed to allow placement of the hand on the contralateral shoulder

subSection.title: Variant 2: Shoulder at Rest, Back of Hand Placed on Ipsilateral Thigh
text: Seated with shoulder exposed
Shoulder:
Neutral flexion - abduction - rotation
Elbow:
90° flexion
Full supination (palm facing ceiling)

content.subtitle: Anatomical Landmarks and Palpation
text: Palpate the scapular spine along its entire length as well as the medial border of the scapula
Also locate the greater tuberosity and the glenohumeral joint

vues.title: Longitudinal View
objectifs: Examination of the infraspinatus (muscle belly & tendon)
Examination of the teres minor (muscle belly & tendon)
positionnement: Place the probe in longitudinal view (relative to infraspinatus fibers) on the scapular spine, just lateral to its center
To better locate and identify structures, slowly scan from superior to inferior to observe and differentiate the scapular spine, trapezius, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus
Once these structures are identified, move the probe laterally to the glenohumeral joint
As the relative paths of these two muscles diverge, it is often necessary to use different probe angles to obtain an optimal image in either case
To better see the teres minor [4]:

texte: The posterior deltoid appears at the top of the image. It appears as a hypoechoic area with visible (comparatively hyperechoic) striations
The humeral head (circular hypoechoic area) is visible in the lower right quadrant of the image

The infraspinatus and teres minor appear in the lower left quadrant, under the deltoid and on the surface of the humeral head. They cannot be clearly distinguished in this image due to their similar path and size.

text: The teres minor and infraspinatus muscles, both located at the posterior aspect of the shoulder, are part of the 4 muscles belonging to the rotator cuff (along with the subscapularis and supraspinatus).

The infraspinatus originates in the infraspinous fossa (scapula) and inserts, via a broad tendon, on the lateral facet of the greater tuberosity, just below the supraspinatus insertion. Although the gross anatomy of the infraspinatus is fairly well known, some important morphological concepts still lack consensus.

In the literature, when the pennation of the infraspinatus is described (it is often omitted), it is reported as either: multipennate, bipennate, compartmentalized, and/or fused with the teres minor [6][7][8][9][10]. However, a recent study [3] noted (in 100% of their 48 subjects) the unequivocal separation of the infraspinatus into 3 heads (superior, middle, and inferior). Each of these heads being clearly delimited by its own fascial envelope, but all being part of the same neuromuscular unit (although this aspect is subject to anatomical variability).

In ultrasonography, the different heads ('partitions') of the infraspinatus are well visible and clearly delimited: to avoid any confusion during structure identification, this concept must be well understood

The teres minor, for its part, originates from a narrow band on the lateral border of the scapula, to also insert on the greater tuberosity (inferior and posterior to the infraspinatus tendon). The teres minor is the smallest muscle of the rotator cuff and, despite having a more oblique 'origin-insertion' axis than the infraspinatus, they remain quite similar to each other. This explains why these two muscles have the same action of external rotation and glenohumeral coaptation.

Over a large portion of its muscle belly, the infraspinatus is not covered by any other muscle. Indeed, the upper half of its origin (infraspinous fossa) is masked by the middle trapezius, while the deltoid (posterior and middle) covers the insertion and lateral portion of the muscle belly (from the middle of the scapular spine). This ease of access makes the infraspinatus a good landmark for examining the posterior (posterolateral) aspect of the shoulder. Additionally, the presence of the scapular spine superiorly provides an additional landmark for identifying surrounding structures.
When viewed above the infraspinous fossa, the muscle belly of the infraspinatus should be almost twice the size of the teres minor [4] (when compared based on their cross-sectional area).

The teres minor, as its name suggests, has a well-defined circular profile that allows, despite the contiguity of rotator cuff structures, to distinguish it well from the infraspinatus (which is flatter and wider) [1].

content.subtitle: Infraspinatus Atrophy [Suprascapular Nerve Neuropathy]
text: As explained in the scapular notches & posterior labrum section, involvement of the suprascapular nerve at the suprascapular notch can cause atrophy of the infraspinatus (and supraspinatus)
As a visual reference, the cross-sectional area of the infraspinatus normally corresponds to twice the cross-sectional area of the teres minor

content.subtitle: Tendon Tears
text: Despite their close proximity and sometimes almost fused appearance, the infraspinatus and teres minor can be subject to isolated tears (relative to each other) and must therefore be examined individually[1].
Quite similar to supraspinatus tears, infraspinatus tendon tears can be partial, complete, or intrasubstance (i.e., affecting the central portion of the tendon without extending to its surface) [4].
Complete tears of the infraspinatus tendon typically show significant retraction, often accompanied by a complete tear of the supraspinatus
Tears classically have a hypoechoic ultrasonographic appearance

content.subtitle: Tendinosis
text: In contrast to tendon tears, infraspinatus tendinosis has a hyperechoic appearance, with swelling at affected sites [4]
